abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Services
            Modernization Project for Ecuador were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: A phased
            approach with well designed benchmarks may be more suitable
            for supporting a reform process at the micro level. Reform
            processes at the micro level need strong political support
            both at the national as well as at the local level. It is
            not advisable to condition resources for badly needed
            rehabilitations in hospitals to commitments to a
            modernization process. Involving private operators in the
            provision of primary health care services needs clearly
            defined roles and well identified groups of beneficiaries.

5083343.trustfund:
TF029378-PHRD - TECH. ASSIST. &
            HOSPITAL REFORM PROJ.,TF032314-ECUADOR - HOSPITAL REFORM PROJECT,TF031670-ECUADOR  - HEALTH SECTOR PROJECT,TF037388-BRAZIL - PHARMACEUTICAL SECTOR STUDY,TF032437-ECUADOR - HEALTH AND NUTRITION,TF032313-ECUADOR - HOSPITAL REFORM PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Health
            Services Modernization Project is to assist in expanding
            access to and improving the quality and efficiency of,
            ambulatory and hospital services, by developing new health
            care organization, financing and managerial models in
            selected provinces and municipalities. The project, in
            conjunction with the II Social Development Project - Health
            and Nutrition (FASBASE Project - Ln. 3510-EC), is expected
            to contribute to the improvement of health status of the
            poor in the medium term, particularly mothers and children
            under 5 years of age. The components include: (a)
            decentralized health systems; (b) hospital modernization;
            (c) policy development, human resources management, and
            consensus building; and (d) project administration.
